section: (2) Making Predictions Related to This Data
text:
(2) Making Predictions Related to This Data
Now, moving from 5100-esque to 5450-specific topics, let‚Äôs think about a decision-making system which utilizes surveillance cameras installed around a given neighborhood. This system aims to identify people‚Äôs faces using these cameras and then, on the basis of a given person \(i\)‚Äôs facial image features \(X_i\), classify them into one of two classes:
\[
\widehat{D}_i = \begin{cases}
0 &\text{if }i\textbf{ Not}\text{ a Predicted Drug User} \\
1 &\text{if }i\textbf{ Is}\text{ a Predicted Drug User}
\end{cases}
\]
It turns out that, given the descriptive (and context-free) definitions of fairness at the core of the Fairness in AI literature, we have almost everything that we need, besides a loss function.
Using a slightly different notation than the one we use in e.g.¬†DSAN 5300 (we can convert between the two notations if need be!), in a fairness context the loss is often parameterized with respect to a given true label value \(y\) and a given prediction for that label \(\widehat{y}\): \(L(\widehat{y}, y)\) tells us the ‚Äúbadness‚Äù of predicting a value \(\widehat{y}\) when the true value that we were trying to predict is \(y\).
One standard loss function, used by pretty much any binary classifier (say, those in scikit-learn) unless the default settings are modified, is the misclassification loss:
\[
L(0, 0) = 0, L(0, 1) = 1, L(1, 0) = 1, L(1, 1) = 0
\]
This loss function assigns a ‚Äúbadness‚Äù of 1 when the prediction was incorrect, and a ‚Äúbadness‚Äù of 0 when the prediction was correct, so that it can be condensed even more using the indicator function \(\mathbb{1}\) into just:
\[
L(\widehat{y}, y) = \mathbb{1}[\widehat{y} \neq y].
\]
We can also represent this loss function in a form that resembles a confusion matrix (which we‚Äôll use a lot from now on!), keeping in mind that it‚Äôs just the same form as a confusion matrix, not a confusion matrix itself:




\(\widehat{D}_i = 0\)
\(\widehat{D}_i = 1\)




\(D = 0\)
0
1


\(D = 1\)
1
0




(2.1) Fairness Definition 1: Statistical Parity
Statistical Independence is satisfied if
\[
\Pr(\widehat{D} = 1 \mid A = 0) = \Pr(\widehat{D} = 1 \mid A = 1)
\]
So, let‚Äôs see how/whether this fairness definition ‚Äúmatches up with‚Äù our intuitions around fairness!
First, let‚Äôs construct a ‚Äúpopulation‚Äù of size \(\nu = 1000\) (since our estimates only go to 3 decimal places max), using the joint distribution derived above, that we can sample from (though, for our purposes here, our ‚Äúsample‚Äù will in fact be the entire population, so that \(N = \nu = 1000\)):

def gen_noisy_feature(pop_race_vec):
  X_bin = pop_df['A'].apply(lambda x: 1 if x == 1 else -1)
  # Random (low chance) flip
  X_mult = rng.choice([1,-1], size=len(pop_race_vec), p=[0.95,0.05])
  X_result = X_bin * X_mult
  X_noise = rng.normal(0, 0.1, size=len(pop_df))
  X_final = X_result + X_noise
  return X_final

def gen_random_feature(pop_race_vec):
  X_rand = rng.normal(0, 0.1, size=len(pop_race_vec))
  return X_rand

def classify(test_Xmat, d_prob_thresh = 0.17):
  test_Xmat_pred = clf.predict_proba(test_Xmat)
  test_d_prob = test_Xmat_pred[:,1]
  test_d_class = np.where(test_d_prob > d_prob_thresh, 1, 0)
  return test_d_class

def construct_population(pD1_given_A0, pD1_given_A1, nu=1000):
  pA0 = 0.846
  pA1 = 1 - pA0
  pD0_given_A0 = 1 - pD1_given_A0
  pD0_given_A1 = 1 - pD1_given_A1
  # Joint probabilities
  pD1_A0 = pD1_given_A0 * pA0
  #print(pD1_A0)
  pD1_A1 = pD1_given_A1 * pA1
  #print(pD1_A1)
  pD0_A0 = pD0_given_A0 * pA0
  #print(pD0_A0)
  pD0_A1 = pD0_given_A1 * pA1
  #print(pD0_A1)
  joint_dist = np.array([
      [pD0_A0, pD1_A0],
      [pD0_A1, pD1_A1]
  ])
  print(joint_dist)
  nu = 1000
  pop_df = pd.DataFrame({'A': [0]*nu, 'D': [0]*nu})
  joint_freqs = nu * joint_dist
  D0_A0_df = pd.DataFrame([{'D': 0, 'A': 0}] * round(joint_freqs[0,0]))
  D0_A1_df = pd.DataFrame([{'D': 0, 'A': 1}] * round(joint_freqs[1,0]))
  D1_A0_df = pd.DataFrame([{'D': 1, 'A': 0}] * round(joint_freqs[0,1]))
  D1_A1_df = pd.DataFrame([{'D': 1, 'A': 1}] * round(joint_freqs[1,1]))
  pop_df = pd.concat([D0_A0_df, D0_A1_df, D1_A0_df, D1_A1_df], axis=0, ignore_index=True)
  #display(pop_df)
  pop_df['X0'] = gen_noisy_feature(pop_df['A'])
  pop_df['X1'] = gen_random_feature(pop_df['A'])
  return pop_df

  cmat = confusion_matrix(race_vec, d_hat, normalize='true')
  pr_DH1_A0 = cmat[0,1]

  pr_DH0_H0 = cmat[0,0]
  pr_DH1_H1 = cmat[1,1]
  return pr_DH0_H0 + pr_DH1_H1

section: (4) Predictive Parity: A Slightly Less Arbitrary, But Slightly More Problematic(?) Fairness Definition
text:
(4) Predictive Parity: A Slightly Less Arbitrary, But Slightly More Problematic(?) Fairness Definition
Building on Statistical Parity, Predictive Parity incorporates the actual accuracy of the predictions, requiring only that the rate of correct predictions is equal for \(A = 0\) and \(A = 1\):
\[
\Pr(D = 1 \mid \widehat{D} = 1, A = 0) = \Pr(D = 1 \mid \widehat{D} = 1, A = 1)
\]

title: Is It Fair? The Issue of Operationalization and ‚ÄúFairness‚Äù in AI
section: (5) Calibration: The Least Bamboozling of the Context-Free Fairness Measures
text:
(5) Calibration: The Least Bamboozling of the Context-Free Fairness Measures
For any given estimation ‚Äúscore‚Äù \(s(X)\) used by the algorithm as a proxy for estimating \(\widehat{\Pr}(D = 1)\)[2], which in turns gets used (e.g., via thresholding) to generate a final prediction \(\widehat{D}\), the probability of using drugs \(\Pr(D = 1)\) is equal for \(A = 0\) and \(A = 1\):
\[
\Pr(D = 1 \mid s(X) = s, A = 0) = \Pr(D = 1 \mid s(X) = s, A = 1), \; \forall s \in [0, 1]
\]
This measure is the least bamboozling in the sense that it directly addresses the underlying ‚Äúrisk scores‚Äù which, if a given machine learning algorithm does not directly compute itself, can at least be inferred by treating the algorithm like a ‚Äúblack box‚Äù.


This notation is used mainly just to emphasize how \(s(X) \in [0, 1]\) is used by the algorithm to generate estimates of the true probability \(\Pr(D = 1)\)/

(a) Eugenia Cheng talk at Google, ‚ÄúThe Art of Logic‚Äù (YouTube)
It‚Äôs the part from 14 minutes onwards where she starts drawing the diagrams relevant to us: ‚Äútracing back‚Äù an ethically-charged scenario from observed consequents (e.g., person gets beaten up and taken off the plane) to the massive collection of hypothesized antecedents (e.g., flight delays, policies of overbooking, capitalism, efficiency of the airline, and the incentives thereof). To map it back into something from the slides for this class: this ‚Äútracing back‚Äù corresponds (in my view) to the term I mentioned in the slides from last week: ‚Äúunraveling history‚Äù.
Hopefully the Eugenia Cheng talk, in combination with this notion of ‚Äúunraveling history‚Äù or ‚Äútracing consequents to antecedents‚Äù, can help you in seeing how difficult it is to answer the question of when to stop doing this ‚Äútracing back‚Äù and start intervening. If I was to keep ranting, I would mention how my ‚Äúsolution‚Äù here, to the extent that ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù are possible, is (i) humans aren‚Äôt fully rational, but we can incorporate the limits of our own rationality into our models of humans in some sense, e.g.¬†as is done in models of boundedly rational; then, with a bounded-rationality-based model in hand, (ii) Bayes rule literally gives us a mathematically ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù rule, given an objective function of ‚Äúchoosing the best course of action given all information available to us at a given moment‚Äù, for which course of action to choose. This essay by Simon DeDeo from Carnegie Mellon University does a better job than I ever could at explaining and justifying why this might be a good model for decision-making under uncertainty (and why it makes sense to call it ‚ÄúBayesian Reasoning‚Äù), despite its horribly pretentious/condescending title :P


(b) Walter Thabit, How East New York Became A Ghetto (2003): PDF
This one is a bit more peripheral to the main topics in this class, but yeah I wanted to bring it up in class and then also send the PDF here because: if data science in urban policy is your jam, it‚Äôs a perfect example of how the data we have nowadays about differential health outcomes and correlates of crime and etc. for different neighborhoods in NYC didn‚Äôt magically ‚Äúappear‚Äù in nice .csv format ‚Äì it exists because of some combination of political organizing and agitation and etc. (which Walter Thabit himself very much took part in), in conjunction with the discrepancies that were pointed out in a more ‚Äúqualitative‚Äù way by works in urban sociology like this one and its precursors‚Ä¶

section: 2. ‚ÄúExploitation‚Äù as Descriptive vs.¬†Normative Term in Economics
text:
2. ‚ÄúExploitation‚Äù as Descriptive vs.¬†Normative Term in Economics
I basically completely stammered my way through answering this question in-class, which I‚Äôm mad at myself for since imo ‚Äúexploitation‚Äù is a 100% perfect example for looking at how words can have entirely different meanings, and how people can make diametrically opposed judgements of their validity, both within and between the ‚Äúdescriptive‚Äù and ‚Äúnormative‚Äù realms.
In this case, analysis/discussion in the descriptive realm could look like: should we attach the label [‚Äúexploitation‚Äù (as descriptive term)] to [equation \(A\)] or [equation \(B\)]? Then, in the normative realm, analysis/discussion could look like: is [‚Äúexploitation‚Äù (as descriptive term, labeling equation \(X \in \{A, B\}\))] morally objectionable? Is it something an institution could feasibly reduce, in theory? And if so, should they use the scarce resources available to them to try and reduce it?
The reason I stammered and felt so embarrassed that I couldn‚Äôt give a good succinct answer is because‚Ä¶ I have no idea how to explain it without sounding like I‚Äôm doing a cringey flex/humblebrag type of thing but here goes:
Princeton University Press literally commissioned me to write a book chapter answering exactly that question back in 2018 lol, as basically part of a little companion book to a new edition of Das Kapital coming out in September this year (as part of my role on the editorial board for that), woohoo! But then, 10% because of covid and 90% because of my inability to finish anything, the chapter still isn‚Äôt finished and isn‚Äôt coming out anytime soon. Worse, it‚Äôs not even helpful to link the pdf draft in its current state (since there are literally like, half-finished equations in it, section headers without text, etc.). But if the question of different ethical perspectives on economically-defined exploitation is interesting to you, I am happy to send you a sloppy-but-finished pdf of the next draft in ~a week or two!
So yeah, embarrassed because I couldn‚Äôt just say ‚Äúread my book!‚Äù given its current disheveled state, SO the resolution to all this is that I‚Äôm just going to link PDFs for two finished and published book! One by a person I mentioned in week 1, John Roemer:

(a) Roemer, Free to Lose: An Introduction to Marxist Economic Philosophy (1988) [PDF], Chs. 2 and 4
This book gives an ‚Äúintuitive‚Äù model of exploitation in plain English in Chapter 2, then a mathematical model with a semi-formal microeconomic definition of exploitation in Chapter 4.1


(b) Morishima, Marx‚Äôs Economics (1973) [PDF], Ch. 5: ‚ÄúSurplus Value and Exploitation‚Äù
If you were an econ major, and especially if you feel good about econometrics stuff that uses linear algebra and matrix equations, you might instead prefer [chapter 5 of this book] by Michio Morishima, which (a) is better in the sense that it uses more standard econ terms, but then (b) is worse in the sense that it is all building to the argument it became famous for (in chapter 14), that Marxian exploitation can be defined without assuming the so-called Labor Theory of Value. Which was interesting in the 70s when it came out, but by 1988 Roemer could mostly just get to the point of defining and discussing exploitation without having to call it Exploitation-but-not-the-kind-thats-defined-using-Labor-Theory-of-Value.
Moving back on-topic to DSAN 5450, though, the Morishima book does have a nice feature in that Chapter 2 is called ‚ÄúHidden Assumptions‚Äù! Where he goes more into what antecedents might be hiding behind the term ‚Äúexploitation‚Äù when it is used by neoclassical economists vs.¬†Marxian economists.

title: Week 2 Resources / Priming Your Brain for HW1
section: 3. HW1: Nuts and Bolts for Fairness in AI
text:
3. HW1: Nuts and Bolts for Fairness in AI
I‚Äôve already written way too much and included way too many PDFs here, but I‚Äôd rather have you overly rather than under-ly prepared for HW1, so I just wanted to give a quick preview of what will be on it, with pointers towards stuff where, if you skim them for example, you‚Äôll know what to do when the homework comes along.
To be clear: most of the contents of these readings will be scary and confusing, since (a) we haven‚Äôt discussed them yet, but also (b) they‚Äôre entire papers/books devoted solely to a single topic that is just one among several topics in this class. And so the idea is just: you can look at these, maybe read the ones that you find sufficiently interesting and ignore the ones you don‚Äôt, and then your brain will be ‚Äúprimed‚Äù for the full-on understanding we‚Äôll develop through slides + homework!

(a) Recovering ‚ÄúRace‚Äù from Proxy Variables
There are a million bazillion books and articles and essays from humanities and the social sciences which I am forcing myself not to list here, because I want to just give yall a short-and-sweet primer you can use to understand the issue with ‚ÄúStep 1: remove the variable called ‚Äòrace‚Äô -> Step 2: problem solved ü•≥üíØ‚Äù from a straightforward, data-science-rooted standpoint. So, for that, I‚Äôd go with this one:

Michael Carl Tschantz, ‚ÄúWhat is Proxy Discrimination?‚Äù (2022)



(b) Discrimination in Advertising

Ali et al.¬†(2019). ‚ÄúDiscrimination through optimization: How Facebook‚Äôs ad delivery can lead to skewed outcomes‚Äù, arXiv Preprint

This topic purposefully comes after (a) though (a) and (b) form a connected pair, since the results in this paper will seem very confusing/suspicious without knowledge about more and less valid ways of ‚Äúrecovering‚Äù race despite absence of a variable called ‚Äúrace‚Äù in the dataset. In the study, they employ an absolutely brilliant method (imo) for discovering discrimination in Facebook‚Äôs ads, but then they do a bit of a ‚Äúsleight of hand‚Äù in just saying ‚Äúwe‚Äôve found that the discrimination is based on race‚Äù, when in fact it‚Äôs ‚Äúwe‚Äôve found that the discrimination is based on [estimated race inferred from proxy variables in a way that you might think is valid but you also might think is invalid]‚Äù.


(c) Confusion matrix fairness
As you might see on the slides we haven‚Äôt gotten to yet, the two main resources I‚Äôm drawing on for this part are:

Chapter 3 of Barocas, Hardt, and Narayanan‚Äôs Fairness in Machine Learning (2023) (the full book is online for free, legally!), titled ‚ÄúClassification‚Äù
Mitchell et al.¬†‚ÄúAlgorithmic Fairness: Choices, Assumptions, and Definitions‚Äù. Annual Review of Statistics and its Applications (2021)

But then, really, an approach to the confusion matrix-based definitions (among others!) that probably fits even better with the class is this presentation from Narayanan (the third author on the above Fairness in ML book), which is refreshing in that it explicitly links fairness definitions with political considerations, rather than trying to ‚Äúhide‚Äù them behind‚Ä¶ math/science/greek letters

Arvind Narayanan, ‚ÄúTutorial: 21 Fairness Definitions and Their Politics‚Äù, from FAT-ML Conference, 2018 (YouTube)



(d) Causal-path fairness

Chapter 5 of the Fairness in Machine Learning book mentioned above is all about causality-based approaches.

It‚Äôs not my favorite starting point tbh, but since I already linked that book, if you find that you like its approach, you can read Ch 6 as well‚Ä¶
To me, a central work in this sphere is:

Lily Hu, ‚ÄúWhat is ‚ÄòRace‚Äô in Algorithmic Discrimination on the Basis of Race?‚Äù, Journal of Moral Philosophy (2024, forthcoming)

This is the distillation of Lily‚Äôs ‚Äúthick constructivist‚Äù theory of race that I mentioned today. But the intuition behind it is broken down into maybe more digestible chunks with pictures and stuff in her blog posts on the Phenomenal World blog. There are 5 things listed there, but the last 2 are interviews so just skip those, I‚Äôm referring to ‚ÄúDisparate Causes Pt. I‚Äù, ‚ÄúDisparate Causes Pt. II‚Äù, and ‚ÄúDirect Effects‚Äù
The thing I‚Äôm scared of with this part, though, is that Lily‚Äôs work is a critique of causal-path fairness definitions, meaning that it can be hard to start there if you don‚Äôt know the thing she‚Äôs critiquing in the first place‚Ä¶ the issue is that the literature on causal pathways is really brutally tough to ‚Äúbreak into‚Äù, honestly. But, probably the book with the fewest barriers to entry‚Äîbasically, a book that you have all the necessary background for, as DSAN students‚Äîis:

Morgan and Winship (2014). Counterfactuals and Causal Inference [PDF]

And then I‚Äôll just say that: a book with the full-on details of everything you‚Äôd ever want to know about causal pathways is:

Judea Pearl (2000). Causality: Models, Reasoning, and Inference [PDF, EPUB]



(e) Reverse fairness
This one was rough tbh, in terms of trying to intro it in Week 2 without the details you‚Äôll have by Week ~7 to 9 when we‚Äôll get into this. Because, it‚Äôs actually completely rooted in a topic that maybe sounds‚Ä¶ either miserably boring or miserably presumptuous at first: ‚ÄúOptimal Tax Rate Theory‚Äù (Optimal labor income taxation / Optimal capital income taxation)
But, if you are willing to see what they mean when they say that a tax rate is quote-unquote ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù, it will get you most of the way to understanding inverse fairness. As you‚Äôre hopefully getting used to, descriptively it means something like:

‚Äú[set of criteria \(C\) and objective function \(f\)] => [tax rate \(z^*\) = maximum of \(f\) subject to constraints \(C\)]‚Äù,

and then normatively it means something like:

‚Äú[if \((C,f)\) characterize your policy goal(s)] \(\implies\) [you ought to set tax rate to be \(z\)]‚Äù.

That‚Äôs not as fun or conclusive/satisfying as they way some economists present it (‚Äúthis is the best most GOATed tax rate and if you don‚Äôt choose this tax rate you‚Äôre dumb and don‚Äôt understand economics!!‚Äù), but it allows us to understand the word ‚Äúoptimal‚Äù as the \(q\) in \(p \implies q\) and move on üòú
Because then, we can use Bayes‚Äô rule to go back and forth: from \(p\) to \(q\), or (!) from \(q\) backwards to \(p\). And in this case that means: given a set of distributional concerns (\(p\)), we can derive an optimal tax rate (\(q\)), OR (!) given an existing tax rate \(q\), we can infer the distributional concerns \(p\) that such a tax rate is implicitly implementing, in the sense of which groups in society are ‚Äúweighted‚Äù higher and lower in the aggregation of individual preferences that manifests in the form of the tax policy.
Since this is so much later in the class, and the HW1 problem will just be tiiny baby steps in that direction, I‚Äôm not too worried about specific articles or anything here ‚Äì instead, I think actually a really helpful thing to read (though it may seem totally out of nowhere) is:

Jean-Paul Sartre (1946) Existentialism is a Humanism [PDF, EPUB], pgs. 30-34

If you use the EPUB: it‚Äôs the series of paragraphs starting with ‚ÄúTo give you an example that will help you to better understand what we mean by abandonment‚Äù; it‚Äôs a section where he talks about a student coming to him for help with ‚Äúethically deciding‚Äù whether to join the anti-Nazi resistance or stay home and care for his sick mother.
The reason I cite that here is because it highlights how, once we‚Äôve set up all these fancy definitions of fairness and causality and social welfare and etc., there is still always going to be an indeterminacy in ethical decision-making: Sartre‚Äôs point in giving this anecdote, in my reading of it at least, was to drive home the fact that he could teach this student 20 years of seminars on ethics, and the student could know 500 ethical frameworks in minute detail, and he would still have to do the hard, agonizing emotional work of making the decision. I think that can be a pretty good lesson to help us ‚Äúzoom out‚Äù a bit, if we find ourselves lost in the sauce of ‚Äúalgorithms are gonna make all our decisions and fix everything!!‚Äù
K I‚Äôm done,
Jeff

title: From Intuitions to Antecedents
text:
The HW1 Question
The question I‚Äôm most concerned about was as follows:






NoteHW1 Q3.2: Rights and Distributive Justice



A group of people is behind the veil of ignorance, debating what rights should be enshrined in a constitution:

They have decided to enshrine a right to private property in their constitution, implying that all individuals in the society have a duty to avoid trespassing on an individual‚Äôs property without their permission. However‚Ä¶
They also want to enshrine the right to urgent medical care, implying that the society has a duty to provide life-saving resuscitation if an individual has a heart attack, for example.

The debate centers around what ought to happen, if both rights are indeed written into the constitution, in the following scenario:

A person \(i\) is walking down the (public) sidewalk and suddenly has a heart attack, falling over into person \(j\)‚Äôs (private) front yard. Paramedics arrive quickly on the scene, but \(j\) isn‚Äôt home to grant or deny permission for the paramedics to enter their front yard to provide medical care to \(i\).

Thus the society is deliberating about a third constitutional provision to cover this case, which means choosing an ethical preference ordering over the following two possible worlds:

\(W_1\): \(j\)‚Äôs right to private property is given higher priority, so that the paramedics must not violate this right to provide the medical care to \(i\)
\(W_2\): \(i\)‚Äôs right to urgent medical care is given higher priority, so that the paramedics must violate \(j\)‚Äôs right to private property and enter the yard to provide the medical care

Under a Rawlsian ethical framework, is this a prioritization that the society could determine a priori (behind the ‚Äúveil of ignorance‚Äù)? Or is Rawls‚Äô ethical framework indeterminate with regard to this ethical decision? If it is not indeterminate, which of the two possible worlds does the Rawlsian system imply should be preferred by a normatively ‚Äúgood‚Äù society?

\(W_1\) should be preferred
\(W_2\) should be preferred
Indeterminate



The correct answer here (in an important way!) was (c) Indeterminate. However, a good number of folks put (b) \(W_2\) should be preferred. I spent a while trying to dig into this outlier, and I think even the most basic explanation‚Äîthat many of yall are extremely busy and just chose the one that sounded intuitively best‚Äîgives us a nice and super-relevant ‚Äúlearning moment‚Äù!
The reason I hyper-fixate on this one commonly-missed question here is because, starting with this slide from Week 1, a key thread running throughout the entire course is the importance of looking at/figuring out antecedents, as the only way to ‚Äúcross the boundary‚Äù between your own beliefs and those of others.

title: From Intuitions to Antecedents
section: Why Can‚Äôt We Just Use Our Intuition?
text:
Why Can‚Äôt We Just Use Our Intuition?
Answering this question is‚Ä¶ somewhat difficult in terms of how ‚Äúmeta‚Äù it is, so, I genuinely apologize (like I did for the Kant writeup) since I don‚Äôt know any way to explain it without using some philosophical jargony things üò≠
The meta-ness comes from the fact that, if a person \(i\) says ‚ÄúI believe \(p\) because \(p\) is obviously true‚Äù, and if that predicate \(p\) itself is ‚ÄúI can use my intuitions to derive (moral) truths‚Äù, then‚Ä¶ essentially an infinite-loop of self-reinforcing certainty is created. At best, an interlocutor \(j\) can only ‚Äúchip away at‚Äù \(i\)‚Äôs‚Äô belief-loop, perhaps by e.g.¬†pointing out cases to \(i\) where their intuition has failed.2
But, with enough ‚Äúchipping‚Äù, \(i\) may be convinced to shift their belief towards something more like a predicate \(q\), ‚ÄúI can use my intuitions, along with my understanding of other people‚Äôs antecedents, to derive moral truths‚Äù, which may then reverberate back to ‚ÄúI believe \(q\) because \(q\) ‚Äòfits with‚Äô the synthesis I‚Äôve formed between my own intuition and the intuitions of others‚Äù3
Nonetheless, my implicit antecedent in writing this is that this shift is possible‚Ä¶ To inject myself into it one last time, for example, one reason why I included that ‚ÄúMy Biases‚Äù slide in W01 is because childhood Jeff absolutely would say things like ‚ÄúI believe \(p\) because \(p\) is obviously true‚Äù, where \(p\) would be things like ‚ÄúIsrael has a right to ‚Äòdefend itself‚Äô‚Äù.4
So, with all that said, the reason why I emphasize ‚Äúantecedent-tracing‚Äù so much (and why (c) being the correct answer is important) is precisely because we need somewhere to ‚Äúgo‚Äù, data-ethics-and-policy-wise, when the types of conflicts outlined in that question arise in our lives as data scientists!
On the one hand, the scenarios in ‚Äúnew employee ethics training‚Äù slides, that I called silly in class (bc they are), usually look something like:

BillyBob (Boss): Hey, Alice, you should falsify some data so we can get published and make millions of dollars!!! I will give you a big ‚ÄòEmployee of the Month‚Äô trophy if you do!!!
Alice (You): Select a proper response in this scenario

And then you‚Äôre supposed to click something like ‚ÄúReport BillyBob to [institutional ethics board]‚Äù, producing the green check and unlocking the ‚Äúcertified ethics master‚Äù achievement.
On the other hand, the data-science-career scenarios that I‚Äôve tried to center in class‚Äîwhich can be more pernicious because they are absent from new-employee ethics seminars and thus don‚Äôt necessarily have obvious answers‚Äîlook more like:

BillyBob (Boss): Hey, Alice, we need to include ‚Äú‚Äú‚Äúcrime‚Äù‚Äú‚Äù as a variable in our model, can you go collect data for that?
Alice (You): Decide (a) how to operationalize ‚Äú‚Äú‚Äúcrime‚Äù‚Äú‚Äú, or (b) push back on BillyBob‚Äôs command on grounds that perhaps we might not want to reify‚Äù‚Äú‚Äúcrime‚Äù‚Äú‚Äù in statistical models given ethical issues with how it is measured in available datasets in our current society

And in these kinds of cases, whether you choose (a), (b), or some other option, the data-ethical choice you make (the purpose of this class, hence the name) will be rooted in some notion of why it‚Äôs a ‚Äúgood‚Äù choice to make under those circumstances. And the answer to that why question is precisely the antecedent:

If you choose (a), for example, perhaps the option is‚Ä¶

‚ÄúGood‚Äù implicitly in terms of reducing your own cognitive dissonance (antecedent = reduction of cognitive dissonance should play a role in ethical decisionmaking), or
‚ÄúGood‚Äù explicitly because your boss asks you why you chose some particular operationalization and you are able to respond with your reasoning (antecedent = justifiability and/or satisfying your boss should play a role in ethical decisionmaking)

If you choose (b), for example, your boss may ask you to elaborate/explain why you‚Äôre not carrying out the command, which would bring in the same justifiability/boss-satisfaction antecedent as in the previous bullet point.

Then, under the antecedent that the resolution of conflicts like this in a given workplace is a function of the involved agents‚Äô relative power5, your ability to frame your answer to the ‚Äúwhy‚Äù question in terms of antecedents that will ‚Äúclick‚Äù with those of your boss will be directly proportional to your ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù in making the ‚Äúright‚Äù decision here!

title: From Intuitions to Antecedents
section: How Does the Specifying-Antecedents Approach ‚ÄúResolve‚Äù This Issue?
text:
How Does the Specifying-Antecedents Approach ‚ÄúResolve‚Äù This Issue?
The increase in likelihood of ‚Äúsuccess‚Äù isn‚Äôt exactly the end of the story here, though. A more holistic way to summarize the answer to the previous section‚Äôs question (the question in the title) is:
Although the approach of ‚Äúwe should operationalize crime as \(\underline{\hspace{60px}}\) because my intuition says that‚Äôs best‚Äù or ‚Äúbecause it‚Äôs obvious‚Äù is pretty much exactly how we carry out our day-to-day data-scientific work subconsciously (e.g., during long R/Python sessions!), the goal of the (Geertz 1973) slide from W01 was to point out how:

Being conscious of our antecedents will be helpful descriptively when we‚Äôre working with others who may ask for justification or may not be convinced by ‚Äúbecause it‚Äôs obvious‚Äù, and
Being conscious of our antecedents will be helpful normatively in terms of helping us evaluate the alignment between our day-to-day subconscious choices and our conscious ethical values

So, to finally get to the takeaway in terms of Q3.2: it‚Äôs important to know that Rawls‚Äô framework, on its own, does not serve as an antecedent for deciding between different rights that a society has decided to establish!
Rawls‚Äô contribution to ethics, in the broadly-construed way we‚Äôve talked about ethics in the first half of the course, was primarily to give a ‚Äúmiddle-ground solution‚Äù to the Problem of Utilitarianism that we discussed (torturing one person to make everyone else happy):






NoteRawls as Solution to Utilitarian Torture-One-Person Problem



Society adopts Utilitarianism, except for a set of Kant-style (deontological) rules regarding the rights of individuals, which thus serve as ‚Äúvetos‚Äù that individuals can use to override Utilitarian decisions.


Rawls, however (importantly!) does not provide a framework for (a) which specific rules should be adopted as rights, or (b) the prioritization of certain rights \(x\) as ‚Äúmore important than‚Äù other rights \(y\).
This ‚Äúhedging‚Äù by Rawls is, ultimately, not specific to Rawls but just one example of the ‚ÄúParadox of Liberalism‚Äù: if we want a full-on, concrete ethical framework‚Äîone which actually specifies the content of what a person/group/organization should do in a particular case‚Ä¶ then we need to add on our own antecedents. For example, an antecedent that would make (a) \(W_1\) should be preferred correct would be:

Rawls‚Äô theory + ‚ÄúThe right to private property is more important than the right to medical care‚Äù

Whereas an antecedent that would make (b) \(W_2\) should be preferred correct would be:

Rawls‚Äô theory + ‚ÄúThe right to medical care is more important than the right to private property‚Äù

And thus, one of those two additional antecedents would need to be added, as a third clause to the constitution being debated, for the question to not be indeterminate!
That‚Äôs‚Ä¶ the best I can do in terms of explaining why Q3.2 is so important, and why we shouldn‚Äôt answer it based on our intuitions, but should think about the antecedents that would lead to each of the three answer choices! For anyone still reading, who wants the full-on deeper philosophical/cultural reasons that I can‚Äôt really do justice to (the more general ‚Äúcrossing the boundary between your own and others‚Äô beliefs‚Äù from the W01 slide), check out:

Geertz (1973), The Interpretation of Cultures (the book pictured in that W01 slide),
Skorupski (1978), ‚ÄúThe Meaning of Another Culture‚Äôs Beliefs‚Äù [Pages 83-106 in this PDF], and
Skinner (2012), ‚ÄúInterpretation, Rationality, and Truth‚Äù [Pages 27-56 in this PDF]

text:
ProPublica vs.¬†Northpointe

Example with 1000s of books, papers, discussions around it!

üö©: obsession with one example may conceal wider range of issues

Northpointe created a ML algorithm called COMPAS, used by court systems all over the US to predict ‚Äúrisk‚Äù of arrestees
In 2016, ProPublica published investigative report documenting COMPAS‚Äôs racial discrimination, in violating equal error rates between black and white arrestees
Northpointe responded that COMPAS does not discriminate, as it satisfies calibration
People have argued about who is ‚Äúright‚Äù for 8 years, with some progress, but‚Ä¶ not a lot

title: Week 5: Context-Free Fairness
text:
COMPAS Overview

When defendants are booked into jail in Broward County, Florida, they are asked to respond to a COMPAS questionnaire with 137 questions, including ‚ÄúWas one of your parents ever sent to jail or prison?,‚Äù ‚ÄúHow many of your friends/acquaintances are taking drugs illegally?,‚Äù and ‚ÄúHow often did you get into fights at school?‚Äù Arrestees are also asked to agree or disagree with the statements ‚ÄúA hungry person has the right to steal‚Äù and ‚ÄúIf people make me angry or I lose my temper, I can be dangerous.‚Äù
Answers are fed into the COMPAS model, which generates an individual risk score reported in three buckets: ‚Äúlow risk‚Äù (1 to 4), ‚Äúmedium risk‚Äù (5 to 7), and ‚Äúhigh risk‚Äù (8 to 10).

title: Week 5: Context-Free Fairness
text:
COMPAS Overview

ProPublica accused COMPAS of racism: ‚ÄúThere‚Äôs software used across the country to predict future criminals. And it‚Äôs biased against blacks,‚Äù read the subheading on the article.
ProPublica found that COMPAS‚Äôs error rates‚Äîthe rate at which the model got it wrong‚Äîwere unequal across racial groups. COMPAS‚Äôs predictions were more likely to incorrectly label African Americans as high risk and more likely to incorrectly label white Americans as low risk.
‚ÄúIn the criminal justice context,‚Äù said Julia Angwin, coauthor of the ProPublica article, ‚Äúfalse findings can have far-reaching effects on the lives of the people charged with crimes.‚Äù

One Solution: Individual Rights




Rights are vetoes which individuals can use to cancel out collective/institutional decisions which affect them (key example for us: right to privacy)
Rawls/liberalism: individual rights are lexically prior to ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù and/or distributional concerns
Why the buzzword ‚Äúlexically‚Äù? Enter (non-scary) math!
We can put lowercase letters of English alphabet in an order: \(\texttt{a} \prec \texttt{b} \prec \cdots \texttt{z}\)
We can put capital letters of English alphabet in an order: \(\texttt{A} \prec \texttt{B} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{Z}\)
What if we need to sort stuff with both types? We can decide that capital letters are lexically prior to lowercase letters, giving us a combined ordering:






Dworkin (1977)





\[
\boxed{\texttt{A} \prec \texttt{B} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{Z} \prec \texttt{a} \prec \texttt{b} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{z}}
\]

You thought I was just talking about letters, but they‚Äôre actually variables: capital letters are rights, lowercase letters are distributive principles

\[
\underbrace{\texttt{A} \prec \texttt{B} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{Z}}_{\mathclap{\substack{\text{Individual Rights} \\ \text{Basic Goods}}}} \phantom{\prec} \prec \phantom{\prec} \underbrace{\texttt{a} \prec \texttt{b} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{z}}_{\mathclap{\substack{\text{Distributive Principles} \\ \text{Money and whatnot}}}}
\]

Letters are where Rawls gets ‚Äúlexically prior‚Äù from, but letters are total orderings (we know where every letter ‚Äústands‚Äù in relation to every other letter)
Better metaphor: UDC (2yr school) rule for allocating basketball tickets:

\[

\]

\(\Rightarrow\) If you‚Äôre a Senior, whether at ‚Äútop‚Äù or ‚Äúbottom‚Äù of a ranking of Seniors, you still (by Constitution) have priority over all Juniors‚Ä¶
Why is this more helpful? Because we don‚Äôt need to define the rankings within classes to know the rankings between classes in this case

Enter Game Theory

A tool for analyzing how individual choices + choices of others \(\rightarrow\) outcomes!





Example: You (\(A\)) and a friend (\(B\)) committed a robbery, and you‚Äôre brought into the police station for questioning.
You‚Äôre placed in separate rooms, and each of you is offered a plea deal: if you testify while your partner stays silent, you go free and they go to jail for 3 years.
Otherwise, if you both stay silent, they have very little evidence and can only jail you for 1 year
However, there‚Äôs a catch: if you both confess, you both get two years in jail, since they now have maximal evidence

Individual Decision-Making




Let‚Äôs think through \(A\)‚Äôs best responses to the possible choices \(B\) could make:
If \(B\) stays silent, what is \(A\)‚Äôs best option?

Staying silent results in 1 year of jail
Testifying results in 0 years of jail
So it is better to testify

If \(B\) testifies, what is \(A\)‚Äôs best option?

Staying silent results in 3 years of jail
Testifying results in 2 years of jail
So it is better to testify

The result: regardless of what \(B\) does, \(A\) is better off testifying!

Imagine you learn that a person received a scholarship (\(D = 1\)); [with equalized positive rates], this fact would give you no knowledge about the race (or sex, or class, as desired) \(A\) of the individual in question. (DeDeo 2016)

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
Achieving Equalized Positive Rates

The good news: if we want this, there is a closed-form solution: take your datapoints \(X_i\) and re-weigh each point to obtain \(\widetilde{X}_i = w_iX_i\), where
\[
  w_i = \frac{\Pr(Y_i = 1)}{\Pr(Y_i = 1 \mid A_i = 1)}
  \]
and use derived dataset \(\widetilde{X}_i\) to learn \(r(X)\) (via ML algorithm)‚Ä¶ Why does this work?
Let \(\mathcal{X}_{\text{fair}}\) be the set of all possible reweighted versions of \(X_i\) ensuring \(Y_i \perp A_i\). Then

\[
\widetilde{X}_i = \min_{X_i' \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{fair}}}\textsf{distance}(X_i', X_i) = \min_{X_i' \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{fair}}}\underbrace{KL(X_i' \| X_i)}_{\text{Relative entropy!}}
\]

The bad news: nobody in the fairness in AI community read DeDeo (2016), which proves this using information theory? Idk. It has a total of 22 citations üòê

One Final Context-Free Criterion: Calibration

A risk function \(r(X)\) is calibrated if

\[
\Pr(Y = 1 \mid r(X) = v_r) = v_r
\]

(Sweeping a lot of details under the rug), I see this one as: the risk function ‚Äútracks‚Äù real-world probabilities
Then, \(r(X)\) is calibrated by group if

\[
\Pr(Y = y \mid r(X) = v_r, A = a) = v_r
\]

Example: ‚ÄúArrow‚Äôs Impossibility Theorem‚Äù

[In theory] It is mathematically impossible to aggregate individual preferences into societal preferences
[The catch] True only if people are restricted to ordinal preferences: ‚ÄúI prefer \(x\) to \(y\).‚Äù No more information allowed
[The way around it] Allow people to indicate the magnitude of their preferences: ‚ÄúI prefer \(x\) 5 times more than \(y\)‚Äù

In this case, though, there are direct and (often) unavoidable real-world barriers that fairness impossibility imposes üòï

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
ProPublica vs.¬†Northpointe

This is‚Ä¶ an example with 1000s of books and papers and discussions around it! (A red flag üö©, since, obsession with one example may conceal much wider range of issues!)
But, tldr, Northpointe created a ML algorithm called COMPAS, used by court systems all over the US to predict ‚Äúrisk‚Äù of arrestees
In 2016, ProPublica published results from an investigative report documenting COMPAS‚Äôs racial discrimination, in the form of violating equal error rates between black and white arrestees
Northpointe responded that COMPAS does not discriminate, as it satisfies calibration
People have argued about who is ‚Äúright‚Äù for 8 years, with some progress, but‚Ä¶ not a lot

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
So‚Ä¶ What Do We Do?

One option: argue about which of the two definitions is ‚Äúbetter‚Äù for the next 100 years (what is the best way to give food to the poor?)


It appears to reveal an unfortunate but inexorable fact about our world: we must choose between two intuitively appealing ways to understand fairness in ML. Many scholars have done just that, defending either ProPublica‚Äôs or Northpointe‚Äôs definitions against what they see as the misguided alternative. (Simons 2023)


Another option: study and then work to ameliorate the social conditions which force us into this realm of mathematical impossibility (why do the poor have no food?)


The impossibility result is about much more than math. [It occurs because] the underlying outcome is distributed unevenly in society. This is a fact about society, not mathematics, and requires engaging with a complex, checkered history of systemic racism in the US. Predicting an outcome whose distribution is shaped by this history requires tradeoffs because the inequalities and injustices are encoded in data‚Äîin this case, because America has criminalized Blackness for as long as America has existed.

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
Why Not Both??

On the one hand: yes, both! On the other hand: fallacy of the ‚Äúmiddle ground‚Äù
We‚Äôre back at descriptive vs.¬†normative:

Descriptively, given 100 values \(v_1, \ldots, v_{100}\), their mean may be a good way to summarize, if we have to choose a single number
But, normatively, imagine that these are opinions that people hold about fairness.
Now, if it‚Äôs the US South in 1860 and \(v_i\) represents person \(i\)‚Äôs approval of slavery, from a sample of 100 people, then approx. 97 of the \(v_i\)‚Äôs are ‚Äúdoes not disapprove‚Äù (Rousey 2001) ‚Äî in this case, normatively, is the mean \(0.97\) the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù answer?

We have another case where, like the ‚Äúgrass is green‚Äù vs.¬†‚Äúgrass ought to be green‚Äù example, we cannot just ‚Äúimport‚Äù our logical/mathematical tools from the former to solve the latter! (However: this does not mean they are useless! This is the fallacy of the excluded middle, sort of the opposite of the fallacy of the middle ground)
This is why we have ethical frameworks in the first place! Going back to Rawls: ‚Äú97% of Americans think black people shouldn‚Äôt have rights‚Äù ¬†\(\nimplies\)‚Äúblack people shouldn‚Äôt have rights‚Äù, since rights are a primary good

What Makes Ethical Judgements ‚ÄúMore Difficult‚Äù?
How did you acquire the concept ‚Äúgood‚Äù?

People pointed to actions with certain properties and said ‚Äúgood‚Äù (and pointed at others and said ‚Äúbad‚Äù), as part of instilling values in you

In doing this, parents/teachers/friends are doing way more than just linking sounds and things in the world (describing): they are also prescribing rules of moral conduct!
Normative concepts go beyond ‚Äúmere‚Äù communication: course of your life / future / [things that matter deeply to people] differ if you act on one set of norms vs.¬†another
\(\implies\) Ethics centrally involves non-arbitrarily-chosen commitments!

One Solution: Individual Rights




Rights are vetoes which individuals can use to cancel out collective/institutional decisions which affect them (key example for us: right to privacy)
Rawls/liberalism: individual rights are lexically prior to ‚Äúefficiency‚Äù and/or distributional concerns
Why the buzzword ‚Äúlexically‚Äù? Enter (non-scary) math!
We can put lowercase letters of English alphabet in an order: \(\texttt{a} \prec \texttt{b} \prec \cdots \texttt{z}\)
We can put capital letters of English alphabet in an order: \(\texttt{A} \prec \texttt{B} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{Z}\)
What if we need to sort stuff with both types? We can decide that capital letters are lexically prior to lowercase letters, giving us a combined ordering:






Dworkin (1977)





\[
\boxed{\texttt{A} \prec \texttt{B} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{Z} \prec \texttt{a} \prec \texttt{b} \prec \cdots \prec \texttt{z}}
\]

You thought I was just talking about letters, but they‚Äôre actually variables: capital letters are rights, lowercase letters are distributive principles

You‚Äôre placed in separate rooms, and each of you is offered a plea deal: if you testify while your partner stays silent, you go free and they go to jail for 3 years.

Staying silent results in 1 year of jail
Testifying results in 0 years of jail
So it is better to testify

If \(B\) testifies, what is \(A\)‚Äôs best option?

Staying silent results in 3 years of jail
Testifying results in 2 years of jail
So it is better to testify

Imagine you learn that a person received a scholarship (\(D = 1\)); [with equalized positive rates], this fact would give you no knowledge about the race (or sex, or class, as desired) \(A\) of the individual in question. (DeDeo 2016)

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
Achieving Equalized Positive Rates

The good news: if we want this, there is a closed-form solution: take your datapoints \(X_i\) and re-weigh each point to obtain \(\widetilde{X}_i = w_iX_i\), where
\[
  w_i = \frac{\Pr(Y_i = 1)}{\Pr(Y_i = 1 \mid A_i = 1)}
  \]
and use derived dataset \(\widetilde{X}_i\) to learn \(r(X)\) (via ML algorithm)‚Ä¶ Why does this work?
Let \(\mathcal{X}_{\text{fair}}\) be the set of all possible reweighted versions of \(X_i\) ensuring \(Y_i \perp A_i\). Then

\[
\widetilde{X}_i = \min_{X_i' \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{fair}}}\textsf{distance}(X_i', X_i) = \min_{X_i' \in \mathcal{X}_{\text{fair}}}\underbrace{KL(X_i' \| X_i)}_{\text{Relative entropy!}}
\]

The bad news: nobody in the fairness in AI community read DeDeo (2016), which proves this using information theory? Idk. It has a total of 22 citations üòê

One Final Context-Free Criterion: Calibration

A risk function \(r(X)\) is calibrated if

\[
\Pr(Y = 1 \mid r(X) = v_r) = v_r
\]

(Sweeping a lot of details under the rug), I see this one as: the risk function ‚Äútracks‚Äù real-world probabilities
Then, \(r(X)\) is calibrated by group if

\[
\Pr(Y = y \mid r(X) = v_r, A = a) = v_r
\]

tldr: We cannot possibly achieve all three of equalized positive rates (often also termed ‚Äúanti-classification‚Äù), classification parity, and calibration (regardless of base rates)
More alarmingly: We can‚Äôt even achieve both classification parity and calibration, except in the special case of equal base rates

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
‚ÄúImpossibility‚Äù vs.¬†Impossibility

Sometimes ‚Äúimpossibility results‚Äù are, for all intents and purposes, mathematical curiosities: often there‚Äôs some pragmatic way of getting around them
Example: ‚ÄúArrow‚Äôs Impossibility Theorem‚Äù

[In theory] It is mathematically impossible to aggregate individual preferences into societal preferences
[The catch] True only if people are restricted to ordinal preferences: ‚ÄúI prefer \(x\) to \(y\).‚Äù No more information allowed
[The way around it] Allow people to indicate the magnitude of their preferences: ‚ÄúI prefer \(x\) 5 times more than \(y\)‚Äù

In this case, though, there are direct and (often) unavoidable real-world barriers that fairness impossibility imposes üòï

We can rank unambiguously on individual events: Jump: Charles \(\succ_J\) Aziza \(\succ_J\) Bogdan
Now, axioms for aggregation:

\(\text{WP}\) (Weak Pareto Optimality): if \(x \succ_i y\) for all events \(i\), \(x \succ y\)
\(\text{IIA}\) (Independence of Irrelevant Alternatives): If a fourth competitor enters, but Aziza and Bogdan still have the same relative standing on all events, their relative standing overall should not change

Long story short: only aggregation that can satisfy these is ‚Äúdictatorship‚Äù: choose one event, give it importance of 100%, the rest have importance 0% üò∞

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
ProPublica vs.¬†Northpointe

This is‚Ä¶ an example with 1000s of books and papers and discussions around it! (A red flag üö©, since, obsession with one example may conceal much wider range of issues!)
But, tldr, Northpointe created a ML algorithm called COMPAS, used by court systems all over the US to predict ‚Äúrisk‚Äù of arrestees
In 2016, ProPublica published results from an investigative report documenting COMPAS‚Äôs racial discrimination, in the form of violating equal error rates between black and white arrestees
Northpointe responded that COMPAS does not discriminate, as it satisfies calibration
People have argued about who is ‚Äúright‚Äù for 8 years, with some progress, but‚Ä¶ not a lot

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
So‚Ä¶ What Do We Do?

One option: argue about which of the two definitions is ‚Äúbetter‚Äù for the next 100 years (what is the best way to give food to the poor?)


It appears to reveal an unfortunate but inexorable fact about our world: we must choose between two intuitively appealing ways to understand fairness in ML. Many scholars have done just that, defending either ProPublica‚Äôs or Northpointe‚Äôs definitions against what they see as the misguided alternative. (Simons 2023)


Another option: study and then work to ameliorate the social conditions which force us into this realm of mathematical impossibility (why do the poor have no food?)


The impossibility result is about much more than math. [It occurs because] the underlying outcome is distributed unevenly in society. This is a fact about society, not mathematics, and requires engaging with a complex, checkered history of systemic racism in the US. Predicting an outcome whose distribution is shaped by this history requires tradeoffs because the inequalities and injustices are encoded in data‚Äîin this case, because America has criminalized Blackness for as long as America has existed.

title: Week 4: Rights, Policies, and Fairness in AI
text:
Why Not Both??

On the one hand: yes, both! On the other hand: fallacy of the ‚Äúmiddle ground‚Äù
We‚Äôre back at descriptive vs.¬†normative:

Descriptively, given 100 values \(v_1, \ldots, v_{100}\), their mean may be a good way to summarize, if we have to choose a single number
But, normatively, imagine that these are opinions that people hold about fairness.
Now, if it‚Äôs the US South in 1860 and \(v_i\) represents person \(i\)‚Äôs approval of slavery, from a sample of 100 people, then approx. 97 of the \(v_i\)‚Äôs are ‚Äúdoes not disapprove‚Äù (Rousey 2001) ‚Äî in this case, normatively, is the mean \(0.97\) the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù answer?

We have another case where, like the ‚Äúgrass is green‚Äù vs.¬†‚Äúgrass ought to be green‚Äù example, we cannot just ‚Äúimport‚Äù our logical/mathematical tools from the former to solve the latter! (However: this does not mean they are useless! This is the fallacy of the excluded middle, sort of the opposite of the fallacy of the middle ground)
This is why we have ethical frameworks in the first place! Going back to Rawls: ‚Äú97% of Americans think black people shouldn‚Äôt have rights‚Äù ¬†\(\nimplies\)‚Äúblack people shouldn‚Äôt have rights‚Äù, since rights are a primary good

text:
What Makes Ethical Judgements ‚ÄúMore Difficult‚Äù?
How did you acquire the concept ‚Äúgood‚Äù?

People pointed to actions with certain properties and said ‚Äúgood‚Äù (and pointed at others and said ‚Äúbad‚Äù), as part of instilling values in you
‚ÄúGrass is green‚Äù just links two descriptive referents together, while ‚ÄúHonesty is good‚Äù takes the descriptive concept ‚Äúhonesty‚Äù and links it with the normative concept ‚Äúgood‚Äù
In doing this, parents/teachers/friends are doing way more than just linking sounds and things in the world (describing): they are also prescribing rules of moral conduct!
Normative concepts go beyond ‚Äúmere‚Äù communication: course of your life / future / [things that matter deeply to people] differ if you act on one set of norms vs.¬†another
\(\implies\) Ethics centrally involves non-arbitrarily-chosen commitments!

In the long evenings in West Beirut, there was time enough to consider where the core of the tragedy lay. In the age of Assyrians, the Empire of Rome, in the 1860s perhaps? In the French Mandate? ‚Ä¶There is Still Hope! I Promise!

Apples-to-applies comparison via Statistical Matching:
Lyall (2020): ‚ÄúTreating certain ethnic groups as second-class citizens [‚Ä¶] leads victimized soldiers to subvert military authorities once war begins. The higher an army‚Äôs inequality, the greater its rates of desertion, side-switching, and casualties‚Äù


Matching constructs pairs of belligerents that are similar across a wide range of traits thought to dictate battlefield performance but that vary in levels of prewar inequality. The more similar the belligerents, the better our estimate of inequality‚Äôs effects, as all other traits are shared and thus cannot explain observed differences in performance, helping assess how battlefield performance would have improved (declined) if the belligerent had a lower (higher) level of prewar inequality.
Since [non-matched] cases are dropped [‚Ä¶] selected cases are more representative of average belligerents/wars than outliers with few or no matches, [providing] surer ground for testing generalizability of the book‚Äôs claims than focusing solely on canonical but unrepresentative usual suspects (Germany, the United States, Israel)

Recap: Ethical Systems and Promise-Keeping






TipOur First Ethical Dilemma ü•≥







Scenario: You just baked a pie, and you promised your friend you‚Äôd give them the pie. You walk to friend‚Äôs house to give them the pie.
Suddenly, you encounter a hostage-taker who will kill their hostage unless someone gives them a pie within 1min. Do you give your pie?

















Consequentialist Ethics \(\implies\) Yes


To be ethical is to weigh expected consequences of your actions
Positive consequences of giving pie (saving a life) outweigh negative consequences (breaking promise)
Ex: Utilitarianism (Jeremy Bentham)
(Complication: Rule Utilitarianism = choose rule that produces greatest good üòµ‚Äçüí´)




Deontological Ethics \(\implies\) No


To be ethical is to live by rules which you would want everyone to follow, even if you following them doesn‚Äôt lead to others following them (non-consequentialist!)
As a rule (a ‚Äúcategorical imperative‚Äù), you must not break promises. (Breaking \(\Rightarrow\) others can also ‚Äúpick and choose‚Äù when to honor promises to you)
Ex: Kantian Ethics (Immanuel Kant)

Lyall (2020): ‚ÄúTreating certain ethnic groups as second-class citizens [‚Ä¶] leads victimized soldiers to subvert military authorities once war begins. The higher an army‚Äôs inequality, the greater its rates of desertion, side-switching, and casualties‚Äù


Matching constructs pairs of belligerents that are similar across a wide range of traits thought to dictate battlefield performance but that vary in levels of prewar inequality. The more similar the belligerents, the better our estimate of inequality‚Äôs effects, as all other traits are shared and thus cannot explain observed differences in performance, helping assess how battlefield performance would have improved (declined) if the belligerent had a lower (higher) level of prewar inequality.
Since [non-matched] cases are dropped [‚Ä¶] selected cases are more representative of average belligerents/wars than outliers with few or no matches, [providing] surer ground for testing generalizability of the book‚Äôs claims than focusing solely on canonical but unrepresentative usual suspects (Germany, the United States, Israel)

Recap: Ethical Systems and Promise-Keeping







Our First Ethical Dilemma ü•≥






Scenario: You just baked a pie, and you promised your friend you‚Äôd give them the pie. You walk to friend‚Äôs house to give them the pie.
Suddenly, you encounter a hostage-taker who will kill their hostage unless someone gives them a pie within 1min. Do you give your pie?



















Consequentialist Ethics \(\implies\) Yes


To be ethical is to weigh expected consequences of your actions
Positive consequences of giving pie (saving a life) outweigh negative consequences (breaking promise)
Ex: Utilitarianism (Jeremy Bentham)
(Complication: Rule Utilitarianism = choose rule that produces greatest good üòµ‚Äçüí´)




Deontological Ethics \(\implies\) No


To be ethical is to live by rules which you would want everyone to follow, even if you following them doesn‚Äôt lead to others following them (non-consequentialist!)
As a rule (a ‚Äúcategorical imperative‚Äù), you must not break promises. (Breaking \(\Rightarrow\) others can also ‚Äúpick and choose‚Äù when to honor promises to you)
Ex: Kantian Ethics (Immanuel Kant)

How Are They Being Compared?




What metric? Over what timespan?
What unit of obs? Agg function? Level of aggregation?





Comparing India‚Äôs death rate of 12 per thousand with China‚Äôs of 7 per thousand, and applying that difference to the Indian population of 781 million in 1986, we get an estimate of excess normal mortality in India of 3.9 million per year. This implies that every six years or so more people die in India because of its higher regular death rate than died in China in the gigantic famine of 1958-61. title: Kantian Ethics: The Hypothetical and Categorical Imperative
text:
Homework 1 had a series of questions where you were asked to distinguish whether a given statement was more ‚Äúdirectly‚Äù implied by Consequentialism or Kantian Ethics: in this writeup, my goals are:
Those two goals, however, are written in chronological order based on when they came up in the class or in office hours! So, for ease-of-explanation pursposes, I will address them in reverse order in the following two sections.

title: Kantian Ethics: The Hypothetical and Categorical Imperative
section: Kantian Ethics and the Push-Button Brain Zapper2
text:
Kantian Ethics and the Push-Button Brain Zapper2
To understand the difference between Consequentialism and Kantian Ethics, at least in the way we employed these terms for HW1, imagine you have a small handheld device called a Brain Zapper3 that works as follows:
The Brain Zapper is really two devices in one, sharing a brain-wave-reader but separated into two CPUs and two screens:

The device on the left side is labeled ‚ÄúConsequentialism‚Äù
The device on the right side is labeled ‚ÄúKantian Ethics‚Äù




Image Credit


Here we‚Äôll model how these two screens would ‚Äúprocess‚Äù the decision of whether or not to do some action \(a\):

We‚Äôll assume your name is Doug, since we need a way to distinguish you from everyone else, but you can replace ‚ÄúDoug‚Äù with your real name!
We‚Äôll denote ‚ÄúDoing \(a\)‚Äù with just the symbol \(a\), whereas
We‚Äôll denote ‚ÄúNot doing \(a\)‚Äù with \(\neg a\), so that
Doug‚Äôs choice set is \(C = \{a, \neg a\}\)

Under these terms, the Brain Zapper activates when Doug start thinking a thought like ‚ÄúShould I choose \(a\) or \(\neg a\)?‚Äù The two sides of the Brain Zapper then both run a series of ultra-advanced societal simulations, but of different kinds:







Utilitarian CPU
Kantian CPU




 Simulate two worlds:
 Simulate two worlds:


\(\mathcal{W}_{a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if Doug chooses \(a\)
\(\mathcal{W}_{a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if everyone in the world adoped rule: [when in this scenario, choose \(a\)]


\(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if Doug chooses \(\neg a\)
\(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if everyone in the world adoped rule: [when in this scenario, choose \(\neg a\)]


 Decide which is better on the basis of some criteria. Since we chose utilitarianism, decide based on utility summed over society:\(\displaystyle \max\left\{ \mathbb{E}[u_i(\mathcal{W}_{a})], \mathbb{E}[u_i(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a})] \right\}\)
 \(a\) is admissible under categorical imperative if \(\mathcal{W}_{a}\) is a world you would feel ok living in.\(\neg a\) is admissible under categorical imperative if \(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a}\) is a world you would feel ok living in.

title: Kantian Ethics: The Hypothetical and Categorical Imperative
text:
‚ÄúBest‚Äù vs.¬†‚ÄúAdmissible‚Äù
So, note that for example, under Utilitarianism it is in some sense ‚Äúunlikely‚Äù that the two actions would be equally good (they would have to both result in the exact same level of expected overall utility forever into the future), whereas under Kantian ethics we might regularly encounter scenarios which give rise to multiple admissible choices:

Choosing between Ranch Dressing and Balsalmic Vinaigrette Dressing on your Greek Salad will usually have a Utilitarian ‚Äúbest‚Äù option: if choosing Ranch provides even 0.0000001 more utility for you, and if choosing it doesn‚Äôt decrease anyone else‚Äôs utility, then Ranch is the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù choice
Both choices will likely be admissible under Kantian ethics, which makes more sense if we look at them one by one:

Would you feel ok living in a world where everyone put Ranch Dressing on their Greek Salads?4
Would you feel ok living in a world where everyone put Balsalmic Vinaigrette Dressing on their Greek Salads?

title: Kantian Ethics: The Hypothetical and Categorical Imperative
text:
A Harder Case

‚ÄúGetting Away With‚Äù Choosing Ranch Dressing vs.¬†‚ÄúGetting Away With‚Äù Speeding
The Kantian approach comes more into play when we think about, e.g., ‚Äúgetting away with‚Äù some action. This was Kant‚Äôs original motivation for proposing an alternative to utilitarianism: he believed Utilitarianism could never compel individual people to act ethically, since they would say, ‚ÄúOk but, if I‚Äôm better off‚Ä¶ why do I care if the rest of society is worse off?‚Äù
The next step in Kant‚Äôs thought process (as in, how he ended up at this conclusion) is way tough to follow, but boils down in Jeff‚Äôs trying-to-simplify-everything-despite-rushing-to-finish-this-writeup brain to something like:

 Morality is intertwined with freedom, in the sense that if we want to be truly moral we have to arrive at our decisions through our own thought processes, driven by internally-generated motivations, rather than on the basis of some externally-given criterion/source of motivation like that of Utilitarianism5. So then [rushing through 40ish years of him changing, updating, augmenting this theory],
 Freely-made decisions grounded in internally-generated motivations must be arrived at via some law(s) that are not ‚Äúinputted‚Äù into our minds from the external world (otherwise, we could just hit people with the Utilitarianism stick for years and years until they internalized Utilitarianism, which is what Britain tried through e.g.¬†their education system in the 19th century, and yet people raised in this system still acted ‚Äúimmorally‚Äù in the Utilitarian sense all the time!), but are instead ‚Äúimmanent‚Äù‚Äîi.e., derived from within the mind itself without reference to external circumstances (height, weight, ability, class, race, gender, etc.)6
 After even more years of thinking about this, Kant‚Äôs final set of works argued that the sole coherent / consistent-in-and-of-itself law that could possibly satisfy this ultra-stringent set of conditions is the Categorical Imperative described above, which is usually translated into English as:

‚ÄúAct only according to that maxim7 by which you can at the same time will that it should become a universal law.‚Äù Kant (1785)


For any clarity beyond this painfully-badly-oversimplified 3-step summary, I refer yall to Korsgaard (1996b), or the series of lectures which aimed to summarize that more-intense book, Korsgaard (1996a), a PDF of which is linked to from the Resources page!


The Case of Speeding
So, now let‚Äôs re-run the Brain Zapper, but with speeding because we‚Äôre late to an appointment (the HW1 example) as our test case.







Utilitarian CPU
Kantian CPU




 Simulate two worlds:
 Simulate two worlds:


\(\mathcal{W}_{a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if Doug chooses to speed
\(\mathcal{W}_{a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if everyone in the world adoped rule: [if late to appointment, speed]


\(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if Doug chooses not to speed
\(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a}\): The world from moment of action onwards if everyone in the world adoped rule: [if late to appointment, don‚Äôt speed]


 Decide which is better on the basis of some criteria. Since we chose utilitarianism, decide based on utility summed over society:\(\displaystyle \max\left\{ \mathbb{E}[u_i(\mathcal{W}_{a})], \mathbb{E}[u_i(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a})] \right\}\)
 Speeding is admissible under categorical imperative if \(\mathcal{W}_{a}\) is a world you would feel ok living in.Not-speeding is admissible under categorical imperative if \(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a}\) is a world you would feel ok living in.



In this case, we are likely to have a pretty significant disagreement between the two approaches:

For the Utilitarian approach, let‚Äôs grant that there really is a low probability of crashing in this scenario (though, the argument could still be made without this assumption, using ideas like ‚Äúbounded rationality‚Äù), and that it is indeed really bad for Doug to be late, so that the expected utility to Doug from making it to the appointment on time outweighs the expected disutility to the rest of society from the low probability of crashing. Then: \(\mathbb{E}[u_i(\mathcal{W}_a)] > \mathbb{E}[u_i(\mathcal{W}_{\neg a})]\), and \(a\) is the ethically ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù choice under this form of the Utilitarian antecedent
For the Kantian approach, speeding would not be admissible, since, e.g., [there are huge huge leaps of inference here, that you would usually have to sto and justify one-by-one‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm simplifying for the sake of finishing this writeup, sryy] everyone speeding whenever they‚Äôre late would give rise to a world filled with a way higher likelihood of car crashes than we already have now, in turn raising the likelihood of crashes which would severely negatively affect Doug specifically (which is the crucial consideration, since we‚Äôre just back at utilitarianism if we judge based on overall likelihood of crashes). In Kant‚Äôs way of arguing, he would then proceed like: since humans cannot rationally will a rule deleterious to themselves8, speeding is inadmissible due to it failing the categorical imperative.

title: Kantian Ethics: The Hypothetical and Categorical Imperative
section: Why It‚Äôs Called the Brain Zapper
text:
Why It‚Äôs Called the Brain Zapper
Lastly, if you‚Äôve gotten this far, I have yet to explain the name of the device! It‚Äôs called the Brain Zapper because, to ‚Äúact ethically‚Äù in the Kantian sense, you must be ready to accept a world where the decisions you make are suddenly ‚Äúzapped‚Äù into the brains of everyone on earth (now and into the future) as a rule!
So, to truly act ethically, you have to be willing to put your money where your mouth is (we‚Äôll return to this phrase, like, a lot as we get towards the end of the semester!): willing to allow the Brain Zapper to send out a Neuralizer-style wave, suddenly binding everyone in the world to follow the implied rule. Does this sound relevant to something we are also concerned with in this class? That‚Äôs right: Laws! Policies! More on this connection coming soon (around week‚Ä¶ 10ish).

section: 2. Linguistic Relativism, Linguistic Determinism, and the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis
text:
2. Linguistic Relativism, Linguistic Determinism, and the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis
Honestly, this question simmered in my brain from the minute it came up until the end of class! So, from the time class ended up until now, I went back and re-read two of the four books that had put these concepts into my brain in the first place. The two I read were:

Marcel Danesi (2021), Linguistic Relativity Today: Language, Mind, Society, and the Foundations of Linguistic Anthropology (Danesi 2021) [PDF; this one is particularly difficult and expensive to obtain a hard copy of!]
John McWhorter (2014), The Language Hoax: Why the World Looks the Same in Any Language (McWhorter 2014): This one I did explicitly mention in class and put it on the slides [EPUB]

While the two I didn‚Äôt re-read, but did impact my brain at some earlier point, were:

Steven Pinker (2005), The Stuff of Thought: Language as a Window into Human Nature (Pinker 2005) [EPUB]
George Lakoff (1987), Women, Fire, and Dangerous Things: What Categories Reveal about the Mind (Lakoff 1987) [PDF]

Besides the time factor, the reason I only re-read the first two is because: (a) I remember feeling like the Pinker book was overly dismissive of the whole idea; as in, I don‚Äôt feel like it gave a very ‚Äúfair trial‚Äù to the nuances of the degrees to which language and thought affect one another. And (b) Lakoff‚Äôs books are‚Ä¶ I feel like I should like them, the specific topics he looks at are fascinating and relevant and important imo, but then when I actually open them up and read them I often feel like the writing is a bit dry and monotonous1.
And, my followup thought on this is: I was too dismissive of the Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis! One of the reasons I settled on the Danesi book at spot #1 is because, I think it does a really good job of separating the strong and weak forms of this hypothesis, and it matches 100% with how Cynthia summarized it in class! So, I hereby delegate Cynthia as the class consultant for language in data ethics and society üòé. The summary I can come up with, trying to synthesize what Cynthia said and how it‚Äôs described in the Danesi book, is that:

Linguistic Determinism, or the Strong Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis, posits that ‚Äúlanguage determines how people think‚Äù (Danesi 2021, x), whereas
Linguistic Relativism, or the Weak Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis, posits that language shapes (without determining) how people think.

Basically, the Danesi book‚Äôs preface mentions the strong version but quickly dismisses it: ‚ÄúFrom the relevant studies, there is little support for the so-called ‚Äòstrong‚Äô version‚Äù (Danesi 2021, x). The first chapter then goes in-depth into the weak version, in a really fascinating way.
I was taking the term ‚ÄúSapir-Whorf Hypothesis‚Äù in general and conflating it with the strong version, and that‚Äôs where my criticism was coming from. I should have phrased what I was saying as: the strong Sapir-Whorf Hypothesis can be problematic, from my perspective, given the implications that could come from believing it to be true when it isn‚Äôt.
In its strong form, for example, it strikes me as alarmingly reminiscent of Samuel Huntington‚Äôs Clash of Civilizations hypothesis (and the many similar and similarly-influential global-cultural claims), which have the effect of telling policymakers something like ‚Äúwe‚Äôll never be able to bridge the humongous gap between ‚ÄòEastern‚Äô and ‚ÄòWestern‚Äô cultures, so they‚Äôll just have to eternally clash with one another, and uh, I hope ‚Äòwe‚Äô win!‚Äù
This is the kind of danger that, in my reading, McWhorter is warning about in the Language Hoax book whose cover was in my slides: just that, we have to be very careful when talking about concepts as fuzzy and hard-to-define as ‚Äúa culture‚Äù or ‚Äúa language‚Äù since, despite their vagueness in theory, they can become reified and morph into dehumanizing claims and then entire books about e.g.¬†the ‚ÄúArab mind‚Äù, and then these kinds of books can hypothetically become ‚Äúthe basis of‚Äù one‚Äôs ‚Äúcultural instruction‚Äù in the US Army, with predictable consequences‚Ä¶

‚ÄúAt the institution where I teach military officers,‚Äù‚Äù as retired U.S. Army Col. Norvell De Atkine writes in the book‚Äôs foreword, ‚ÄúThe Arab Mind forms the basis of my cultural instruction.‚Äù (from Slate, ‚ÄúInside The Arab Mind: What‚Äôs wrong with the White House‚Äôs book on Arab nationalism‚Äù)

With that said, I don‚Äôt think there‚Äôs anything in Whorf‚Äôs original description of the idea that lends itself to this kind of cultural essentialism! I think the following quote from Whorf, quoted at the beginning of the Danesi book, makes the distinction really clear:

We are thus introduced to a new principle of relativity, which holds that all observers are not led by the same physical evidence to the same picture of the universe, unless their linguistic backgrounds are similar, or can in some way be calibrated. (Whorf 1956, 229)

Basically, this quote is how I‚Äôll remember Sapir-Whorf as linguistic relativism, rather than determinism, from now on!
